column4: uhh, quick question, im using Ubuntu Hardy, no matter what I do after I edit /etc/network/interfaces, it refuses to assign a static IP
why wont Ubuntu allow me to manually configure my eth connections?
I end up with the same defaulted garbage each time I change my network interfaces file
it should, what's the problem?
no idea, it keeps defaulting to a DHCP address
hmm did you disable "roaming" or whatever it's called
yeah, but it wont disable, roaming seems to be the only thing that works
I think persistent rules was ruining me
persistence rules? Not familar with that...
something that "helps" you by not allowing certain things to be changed, /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules
oh, udev... ya ya... those are good things actually (I believe they ensure a given piece of hardware is always assigned the same device file)
welp, ill see if that was my prob
Without that, you may find the ethernet devices change around (if you install a new one)
i didnt try that yet, no
have you ever had a problem with Ubuntu having a stranglehold on your network settings?
I think some of the files in /etc related to networking are generated from XML files (in gconf?)
To restore some temporary sanity, did you try chattr +i on your interface file?
this is nuts, ifconfig gives me eth0 and eth2, i do sudo ifdown eth2 and it tells me eth2 isnt valid (and it shouldnt be, its not in my interfaces file)
that wll make the file immutable (not a solution, but will prevent it from being overwritten at least)
its not being overwritten
